case_name: State of Madras v. M/s Radio Electricals Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 334, 335 and 338 of 1965 were filed by the State of Madras by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by Special Leave from the judgment and orders dated January 1, 1963, November 7, 1962 and November 4, 1963 of the Madras High Court in Tax Case No. 170 of 1961 Civil Revision Petition No. 105 of 1961 and Tax Case No. 153 of 1963 respectively.

facts.text: Madras High Court delivered judgment dated January 1, 1963 in Tax Case No. 170 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by Special Leave from the judgment and orders dated January 1, 1963, November 7, 1962 and November 4, 1963 of the Madras High Court in Tax Case No. 170 of 1961 Civil Revision Petition No. 105 of 1961 and Tax Case No. 153 of 1963 respectively.

facts.text: Madras High Court delivered order dated November 7, 1962 in Civil Revision Petition No. 105 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: November 7, 1962 and November 4, 1963 of the Madras High Court in Tax Case No. 170 of 1961 Civil Revision Petition No. 105 of 1961 and Tax Case No. 153 of 1963 respectively. Bishan Narain and A. V. Rangam, for the appellants  in C.As. Nos. 334 and 335 of 1965 . V. Rangam, for the appellant  in C.A. No. 338/1965 . R. Chaudhuri, for the respondent  in C. A. No 334/1965 . D. Karkhanis, O.C. Mathur, J.B. Dadachanji and Ravinder Narain,for the respondents  in C.As. Nos. 335 and 338/1965 .

facts.text: Madras High Court delivered order dated November 4, 1963 in Tax Case No. 153 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: November 7, 1962 and November 4, 1963 of the Madras High Court in Tax Case No. 170 of 1961 Civil Revision Petition No. 105 of 1961 and Tax Case No. 153 of 1963 respectively.

facts.text: M/s Radio Electricals Ltd. carries on business in the State of Madras in electrical equipment and is registered as a dealer under the Central Sales Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: M s Radio Electricals Ltd., respondents in this appeal on business in the State of Madras in electrical equipment and are registered as dealers under the Central Sales Tax Act.

facts.text: Bombay State Electricity Board, Saurashtra Division, purchased transformers and other goods worth Rs. 1,42,020/- from M/s Radio Electricals Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: The Bombay State Electricity Board, Saurashtra Division, which is engaged in the production of electric energy purchased transformers and other goods of the total value of Rs. 1,42,020/- from M s. Radio Electricals Ltd. and the latter claimed in proceeding for assessment for Central sales-tax for the year 1957-58 that they were liable to pay tax at the rate of 1 per cent on the turnover under S. 8 1  of the Central Sales Tax Act.

facts.text: M/s Radio Electricals Ltd. claimed concessional tax rate of 1% under Section 8(1) of Central Sales Tax Act for turnover of sales to Bombay State Electricity Board in assessment year 1957-58.

anchor.surface_text: from M s. Radio Electricals Ltd. and the latter claimed in proceeding for assessment for Central sales-tax for the year 1957-58 that they were liable to pay tax at the rate of 1 per cent on the turnover under S. 8 1  of the Central Sales Tax Act.

facts.text: Deputy Commercial Tax Officer rejected the claim for concessional rate by M/s Radio Electricals Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: The Deputy Commercial Tax Officer rejected the claim on the ground that the Bombay State Electricity Board was number a dealer engaged in selling goods and merely because they held a registration certificate, the goods sold to the Board companyld number be admitted to the companycessional rate of tax under S. 8 1  of the Act.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner of Commercial Taxes confirmed the order of Deputy Commercial Tax Officer in Radio Electricals case.

anchor.surface_text: The Appeal late Assistant Commissioner of Commercial Taxes companyfirmed the order on the ground that transformers and other goods purchased by the Electricity Board for use in the production of electrical energy were number intended, to be used in the manufacture of goods for sale within the meaning of S. 8 3   b  of the Central Sales Tax, Act, because electricity was number at the material time goods within the meaning of the Act.

facts.text: Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal, Madras confirmed the order of Appellate Assistant Commissioner in Radio Electricals case.

anchor.surface_text: The order passed by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner was companyfirmed by the Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal, Madras. The High Court, following an earlier judgment in Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes, Madras Division, v. Manohar Brothers 1  modified the order holding that if the selling dealer within the State produces a certificate in Form C setting out one or more of the purposes in S. 8 3  b  of the Act,

facts.text: Madras High Court modified the Tribunal's order in Radio Electricals case, allowing concessional rate for turnover of Rs. 47,340/- but denying for Rs. 42,080/- .

anchor.surface_text: The High Court then held that out of the certificates in Form C produced by the selling dealer, certificates in respect of a turnover of Rs. 42,080/- set out the purpose as manufacture of electrical energy and since this was number one of the purposes mentioned in S. 8 3  b  of the Act as it stood at the relevant time, the Sales Tax authority was right in denying the benefit of the rate under S. 8  1  to the assessee, but with regard to a turnover of  1  13 S.T.C. 686. Rs. 47,340/- the Sales Tax authority was bound to accept the certificates in Form C produced by the assessee even though the certificates companytained all the purposes mentioned in the prescribed form, and numberpurpose was struck out.

facts.text: M/s Stanes Motors (South India) Ltd. are dealers in automobiles, tractors and spare parts.

anchor.surface_text: The facts which give rise to Civil Appeal No. 335 are these M s Stanes Motors  South India  Ltd.-respondents in this appeal are dealers in automobiles, tractors and spare parts.

facts.text: M/s Stanes Motors claimed concessional rate under s.8(1) on turnover of Rs. 1,38,572/12/- from sale of tractors to four tea factories in Kerala for year 1957-58.

anchor.surface_text: For the year 1957-58 they claimed benefit of companycessional rates under s. 8 1  on a turnover of Rs. 1,38,572/12/- resulting from sale of tractors supplied to certain tea factories in the State of Kerala.

facts.text: Four tea factories in Kerala, registered dealers, delivered Form C certificates to M/s Stanes Motors stating tractors intended for use in manufacture of tea for sale.

anchor.surface_text: The purchasing dealers who were four tea factories registered as dealers under the Act delivered to the respondents certificates in Form C declaring that the tractors purchased by them were in. tended for use in the manufacture of tea for sale.

facts.text: Tax Officer denied concessional rate to M/s Stanes Motors on sales of tractors to tea factories.

anchor.surface_text: In the view of the Tax Officer benefit of the companycessional rate companyld number be claimed in respect of those sales, since the tractors were number for resale and the tractors were number directly relatable to the manufacturing process.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed Tax Officer's order in Stanes Motors case.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal, the order passed by the Tax Officer was companyfirmed by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner. He held that the tractors which were used for transporting tea leaves from the plantations to the factories cannot be said to be used in the manufacture of goods for sale.

facts.text: Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal held M/s Stanes Motors entitled to concessional rate for sales to two out of four tea factories.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal to the Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal, it was held that the respondents were entitled to the companycessional rate in respect of sales to two out of the four factories, which held certificates of registration in Form B specifying machinery as one of the items under s. 8 3  b .

facts.text: Madras High Court confirmed the Tribunal's order in Stanes Motors case in revisional jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Madras companyfirmed the order passed by the Tribunal in exercise of its revisional jurisdiction.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed Civil Appeal No. 334 of 1965 with costs.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal No. 334 therefore fails and is dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed Civil Appeals Nos. 335 and 338 of 1965 with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In Appeals Nos. 335 338 the respondent is the same assessee, and companymon questions for different periods are raised. These appeals also fail and are dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Respondent in Civil Appeals Nos. 335 and 338 is the same assessee.

anchor.surface_text: In Appeals Nos. 335 338 the respondent is the same assessee, and companymon questions for different periods are raised.

concepts.unlisted_description: Concessional rate of tax for inter-state sales to registered dealers.

issues.text: When a purchasing dealer in one State furnishes in Form C prescribed under the Central Sales Tax Registration Turnover Rules, 1957, to the selling dealer in another State a declaration, certifying that the goods ordered, purchased or supplied are covered by the certificate of registration obtained by the purchasing dealer in Form B prescribed under r. 5(1) of the Central Sales Tax Registration Turnover Rules, 1957, and that the goods are intended for resale, or for use in manufacture of goods for sale, or for use in the execution of contracts, or for packing of goods for resale, and that declaration is produced by the selling dealer, is it open to the Sales Tax authority under the Central Sales Tax Act to deny to the selling dealer the benefit of concessional rates under s. 8(1) of the Central Sales Tax Act, 1956 on the view that the certificate in Form C mentions more purposes than one for which the goods are intended to be used, or that the goods are incapable of being used for the purpose for which they are declared to be purchased, or that the goods are applied for some other purpose not mentioned in the certificate in Form C?

anchor.surface_text: When a purchasing dealer in one State furnishes in Form C prescribed under the Central Sales Tax  Registration Turnover  Rules, 1957, to the selling dealer in another State a declaration, certifying that the goods ordered, purchased or supplied are covered by the certificate of registration obtained by the purchasing dealer in Form B prescribed under r. 5 1  of the Central Sales Tax  Registration Turnover  Rules, 1957,

issues.text: Whether a certificate in Form C which specifies more purposes than one for which the goods are intended to be used by the purchasing dealer is invalid?

anchor.surface_text: Counsel also submitted that a certificate in Form C which specifies more purposes than one for which the goods are intended to be used by the purchasing dealer is invalid.

issues.text: Whether the Sales Tax authority is competent to ascertain whether the goods specified in the purchasing dealer's certificate can be used for the purpose mentioned in the certificate in Form C, or whether the goods were applied for the purpose for which they were purchased?

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the State of Madras contends that the Commercial Tax Officer is invested with authority under the Act to scrutinise the transactions in respect of which the claim to concessional rate of tax is made, and he is competent to ascertain not only whether the certificate in Form C is genuine, but whether the certificate is valid in law, whether the purchasing dealer holds a valid certificate of registration in Form B, whether the goods specified in the purchasing dealers certificate can be used for the purpose mentioned in the certificate in Form C, and whether the goods were applied for the purpose for which they were purchased.

issues.text: Whether the correctness or propriety of the satisfaction of the notified authority in issuing the certificate in Form B specifying certain goods can be challenged by the Sales Tax Officer in assessment proceedings?

anchor.surface_text: Correctness or propriety of satisfaction of the notified authority in issuing the certificate in Form B that the goods are likely to be required for the purpose of the business would not however be again open to challenge before another taxing authority in proceedings for assessment of tax.

arguments.claim: Commercial Tax Officer is competent to ascertain whether the goods specified in the purchasing dealer's certificate can be used for the purpose mentioned in Form C and whether the goods were applied for the purpose for which they were purchased

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the State of Madras contends that the Commercial Tax Officer is invested with authority under the Act to scrutinise the transactions in respect of which the claim to concessional rate of tax is made, and he is competent to ascertain not only whether the certificate in Form C is genuine, but whether the certificate is valid in law, whether the purchasing dealer holds a valid certificate of registration in Form B, whether the goods specified in the purchasing dealers certificate can be used for the purpose mentioned in the certificate in Form C, and whether the goods were applied for the purpose for which they were purchased.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: rchasing dealer may again be carrying on business as a, manufacturer, as a building, installation or repair companytractor, and as a dealer in goods,

arguments.court_reasoning: Not for Tax Officer to enquire into use or capability; determined by notified authority issuing Form B after objective satisfaction

arguments.claim: Form C without striking out alternatives is valid representation that goods for all or any purposes mentioned

anchor.surface_text: When the purchasing dealer furnishes a certificate in Form C without striking out any of the four alternatives, it is a representation that the goods purchased are intended to be used for all or any of the purposes, and the certificate complies with the requirements of the Act and the Rules.

arguments.claim: Satisfaction under r.5(1) for Form B is objective after quasi-judicial enquiry and binding on assessing authority; cannot challenge whether goods usable for purpose

anchor.surface_text: The authority issuing the certificate under r.5(1)... Satisfaction which is contemplated by r. 5 is objective, and may be arrived at upon a quasijudicial enquiry... Correctness or propriety of satisfaction of the notified authority in issuing the certificate in Form B... would not however be again open to challenge before another taxing authority in proceedings for assessment of tax.

arguments.claim: Selling dealer entitled to concessional rate if Form C genuine and goods covered by purchasing dealer's Form B; no duty to enquire into actual application or notified authority's satisfaction

If he is satisfied on these two matters... the selling dealer is under no further obligation to see to the application of the goods... Penalty for misapplication on purchasing dealer under s.10.

arguments.claim: High Court erred in holding C Form conclusive with no enquiry by assessing authority

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant contended that the view expressed by the High Court in the judgments under appeal was in any case erroneous, because they held that a C Form certificate produced by the selling dealer is conclusive of the right to the concessional rate of tax, and that no enquiry whatever may be made by the assessing authority.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: lling dealer becomes under law entitled to the benefit of section 8 1  of the Act. It is numberfunction of the selling dealer to enter into a judicial

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court observation inaccurate re no enquiry into Form B coverage, but agrees no further enquiry into use

holdings.text: When the purchasing dealer furnishes a certificate in Form C without striking out any of the four alternatives, it is a representation that the goods purchased are intended to be used for all or any of the purposes, and the certificate complies with the requirements of the Act and the Rules.

anchor.surface_text: When the purchasing dealer furnishes a certificate in Form C without striking out any of the four alternatives, it is a representation that the goods purchased are intended to be used for all or any of the purposes, and the certificate complies with the requirements of the Act and the Rules.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Act and Rules do not impose obligation to declare only one purpose; multiple purposes allowed as goods may serve various uses or intent undecided; printed form permits retention of alternatives.

holdings.text: The Sales Tax authority is competent to scrutinise whether Form C is genuine and whether goods are covered by purchasing dealer's Form B registration certificate, but it is not for the Tax Officer to hold an enquiry whether the goods can be used for the declared purpose or were actually used for that purpose.

anchor.surface_text: The Sales Tax authority is, of course, competent to scrutinise the certificate to find out whether the certificate is genuine. He may also, in appropriate cases, when he has reasonable grounds to believe that the goods purchased are not covered by the registration certificate of the purchasing dealer, make an enquiry about the contents of the certificate of registration of the purchasing dealer. But it is not for the Tax Officer to hold an enquiry whether the goods specified in the certificate of registration of the purchaser can be used by him for any of the purposes mentioned by him in Form C, or that the goods purchased have in fact not been used for the purpose declared in the certificate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Authority checks genuineness and coverage by Form B; usability and actual use determined by notified authority issuing Form B after enquiry; prevents double challenge.

holdings.text: Satisfaction contemplated by r.5(1) for issuing Form B is objective, arrived at upon quasi-judicial enquiry, and correctness or propriety of that satisfaction cannot be challenged by another taxing authority in assessment proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: The authority issuing the certificate under r.5(1), as expressly stated in the rule, has, before issuing a registration certificate, to be satisfied after making such enquiry as it thinks necessary that the particulars contained in the application are correct and complete. ... Satisfaction which is contemplated by r. 5 is objective, and may be arrived at upon a quasijudicial enquiry. ... Correctness or propriety of satisfaction of the notified authority in issuing the certificate in Form B that the goods are likely to be required for the purpose of the business would not however be again open to challenge before another taxing authority in proceedings for assessment of tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule requires objective satisfaction via enquiry; precedents confirm; res judicata-like effect prevents re-litigation by assessing authority.

holdings.text: If goods are specified in the purchasing dealer's Form B certificate of registration, Sales Tax Officer cannot deny concessional rate to selling dealer on ground that goods cannot be used by purchasing dealer for the purpose of his business.

anchor.surface_text: If therefore goods are specified in the certificate of registration in Form B it is not open, when a claim is made in respect of the purchases of those goods for the application of concessional rate of tax, to the Sales Tax Officer to deny to the selling dealer of those goods the benefit on the ground that the goods specified cannot be used by the purchasing dealer for the purpose of his business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Form B specification conclusive on usability for business purposes; assessing authority bound by notified authority's determination.

holdings.text: Selling dealer entitled to concessional rate under s.8(1) upon production of valid Form C declaration; no further obligation to enquire into actual application of goods or notified authority's satisfaction; penalty for misapplication lies on purchasing dealer under s.10.

anchor.surface_text: If he is satisfied on these two matters, on a representation made to him in the manner prescribed by the Rules, and the representation is recorded in the certificate in Form C the selling dealer is under no further obligation to see to the application of the goods for the purpose for which it was represented that the goods were intended to be used. If the purchasing dealer misapplies the goods he incurs a penalty under s. 10.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Seller relies on prescribed representations; no control over purchaser; policy avoids burdening innocent seller; penalizes misuser.

holdings.text: Observation in High Court judgment that selling dealer need not enquire if requirement within Form B is inaccurate; selling dealer and assessing authority may check Form B coverage, but not usability which is for issuing authority.

anchor.surface_text: Observation of the High Court that the selling dealer may not enquire whether the requirement is not within the certificate of registration of the purchasing dealer is not accurate. But whether the goods specified in the registration certificate in Form B can be used for the purpose is not for the selling dealer to determine. That is a matter which has already been determined by the notified authority issuing the certificate of registration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Qualifies High Court view; both can verify coverage but defer to issuer on purpose suitability.

holdings.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 334, 335 and 338 of 1965 fail and are dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal No. 334 therefore fails and is dismissed with costs. In Appeals Nos. 335 338 the respondent is the same assessee, and common questions for different periods are raised. These appeals also fail and are dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of above principles to facts upholds High Court; State claims rejected.

anchor.surface_text: 16 S.T.C. 563, referred to. CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 334, 335 and 338 of 1965. precedents.citation: Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes, Madras Division, v. Manohar Brothers 13 S.T.C. 686

anchor.surface_text: Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes, Madras Division, v. Manohar Brothers 1 modified the order holding that if the selling dealer within the State produces a certificate in Form C setting out one or more of the purposes in S. 8 3  b  of the Act, and if the Sales Tax authorities on behalf of the State do number deny that the purchasing dealer is a registered dealer, the selling dealer will number be denied the companycessional rate of tax under the Act, even if it transpires that the purchasing dealer has utilised the goods for purposes other than those mentioned in the certificate of registration. The High Court then held that out of the certificates in Form C produced by the selling dealer, certificates in respect of a turnover of Rs. 42,080/- set out the purpose as manufacture of electrical energy and since this was number one of the purposes mentioned in S. 8 3  b  of the Act as it stood at the relevant time, the Sales Tax authority was right in denying the benefit of the rate under S. 8  1  to the assessee, but with regard to a turnover of  1  13 S.T.C. 686.

precedents.case_name: Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes, Madras Division v. Manohar Brothers
precedents.cited_proposition: if the selling dealer produces a certificate in Form C setting out one or more of the purposes in S. 8(3)(b) of the Act, and the Sales Tax authorities do not deny that the purchasing dealer is registered, the selling dealer cannot be denied concessional rate even if goods misused by purchaser
precedents.cited_holding: selling dealer entitled to concessional rate upon production of Form C by registered dealer

precedents.citation: Indian Copper Corporation Ltd. v. Commissioner of Commercial Taxes, Bihar Others 1965 11. S.C.R. 900, 16 S.T.C. 563

anchor.surface_text: e.g. Indian Copper Corporation Ltd. v. Commissioner of Commercial Taxes, Bihar Others 1  and J. Cotton Spinning Weaving Co. Ltd., v. The Sales Tax Officer, Kanpur Another 1 . On the plain words used in s. 7 and the Rules, it is companytemplated that the certificate of registration may only be issued after an objective satisfaction by the numberified authority that the specified goods are likely to be needed for the purpose of the business of the registered dealer, and that satisfaction is open to challenge in an appropriate proceeding before the High Court and even before this Court. anchor.surface_text: When the purchasing dealer furnishes a certificate in Form C without striking out any of the four alternatives, it is a representation that the goods purchased are intended to be used for all or any of the purposes, and the certificate complies with the requirements of the Act and the Rules.

edges.explanation: h2 holding on Sales Tax authority's competence to scrutinise Form C and Form B coverage addresses aspects of i1 issue on furnishing Form C declarations

anchor.surface_text: The Sales Tax authority is, of course, competent to scrutinise the certificate to find out whether the certificate is genuine. He may also, in appropriate cases, when he has reasonable grounds to believe that the goods purchased are not covered by the registration certificate of the purchasing dealer, make an enquiry about the contents of the certificate of registration of the purchasing dealer. But it is not for the Tax Officer to hold an enquiry whether the goods specified in the certificate of registration of the purchaser can be used by him for any of the purposes mentioned by him in Form C, or that the goods purchased have in fact not been used for the purpose declared in the certificate.

edges.explanation: The holding explicitly states that the correctness or propriety of the objective satisfaction cannot be challenged, directly addressing and answering the issue of whether such satisfaction in issuing Form B can be challenged.

anchor.surface_text: The authority issuing the certificate under r.5(1), as expressly stated in the rule, has, before issuing a registration certificate, to be satisfied after making such enquiry as it thinks necessary that the particulars contained in the application are correct and complete. ... Satisfaction which is contemplated by r. 5 is objective, and may be arrived at upon a quasijudicial enquiry. ... Correctness or propriety of satisfaction of the notified authority in issuing the certificate in Form B that the goods are likely to be required for the purpose of the business would not however be again open to challenge before another taxing authority in proceedings for assessment of tax.

anchor.surface_text: If therefore goods are specified in the certificate of registration in Form B it is not open, when a claim is made in respect of the purchases of those goods for the application of concessional rate of tax, to the Sales Tax Officer to deny to the selling dealer of those goods the benefit on the ground that the goods specified cannot be used by the purchasing dealer for the purpose of his business.
